text.0: the faithful one immortal among mortals a god among the gods appointed envoy.
text.1: priest best at worship must shine forth in glory  agni shall be raised high with mans oblations.
text.2: born for us here this day o son of vigour between both races of born beings agni.
text.3: thou farest as an envoy having harnessed sublime one thy strongmuscled radiant stallions.
text.4: i laud the ruddy steeds who pour down blessing dropping oil flectest through the thoualit of order.
text.5: yoking red horses to and fro thou goest between you deities and mortal races.
text.6: aryaman mitra varuṇa and indra with viṣṇu of the gods maruts and aśvins.
text.7: these agni with good car and steeds bring hither most bountiful to folk with fair oblations.
text.8: agni be this our sacrifice eternal with brave friends rich in kine and sheep and horses.
text.9: rich asura in sacred food and children in full assembly wealth broadbased and during.
text.10: the man who sweating brings for thee the fuel and makes his head to ache thy faithful servant.
text.11: agni to him be a selfstrong protector guard him from all who seek to do him mischief.
text.12: who brings thee food though thou hast food in plenty welcomes his cheerful guest and speeds him onward.
text.13: who kindles thee devoutly in his dwellingto him be wealth secure and freely giving.
text.14: whoso sings praise to thee at eve or morning and with oblation doth the thing thou lovest.
text.15: in his own home even as a goidgirt courser rescue him from distress the bounteous giver.
text.16: whoso brings gifts to thee immortal agni and doth thee service with uplifted ladle.
text.17: let him not sorely toiling lose his riches let not the sinners wickedness enclose him.
text.18: whose wellwrought worship thou acceptest agni thou god a mortals gift thou liberal giver.
text.19: dear be his sacrifice to thee most youthful and may we strengthen him when he adores thee.
text.20: may he who knows distinguish sense and folly of men like straight and crooked backs of horses.
text.21: lead us o god to wealth and noble offspring keep penury afar and grant us plenty.
text.22: this sage the sages neer deceived commanded setting him down in dwellings of the living.
text.23: hence mayst thou friendly god with rapid footsteps behold the gods wonderful fair to look on.
text.24: good guidance hast thou for the priest o agni who youngest god with outpoured soma serves thee.
text.25: ruler of men thou joyous god bring treasure splendid and plentiful to aid the toiler.
text.26: now all that we thy faithful servants agni have done with feet with hands and with our bodies.
text.27: the wise with toil the holy rite have guided as those who frame a car with manual cunning.
text.28: may we seven sages first in rank engender from dawn the mother men to be ordainers.
text.29: may we aṅgirases be sons of heaven and radiant burst the wealthcontaining mountain.
text.30: as in the days of old our ancient fathers speeding the work of holy worship agni.
text.31: sought pure light and devotion singing praises they cleft the ground and made red dawns apparent.
text.32: gods doing holy acts devout resplendent smelting like ore their human generations.
text.33: enkindling agni and exalting indra they came encompassing the stall of cattle.
text.34: strong one he marked themand the gods before themlike herds of cattle in a foodful pasture.
text.35: there they moaned forth their strong desire for mortals to aid the true the nearest one the living.
text.36: we have worked for thee we have laboured noblybright dawns have shed their light upon our worship.
text.37: adding a beauty to the perfect agni and the gods beauteous eye that shines for ever.
text.38: agni disposer we have sung these praises to thee the wise do thou accept them gladly.
text.39: blaze up on high and ever make us richer give us great wealth o thou whose boons are many.
